<span key="566adc76a36c40ebbb4a53e04f35f55e"><span offset-key="566adc76a36c40ebbb4a53e04f35f55e:0">How to Read This Guide</span></span>

<span key="890509dc40ec4b56bc12fde4b1803530"><span offset-key="890509dc40ec4b56bc12fde4b1803530:0">In this guide, we will examine the building blocks of React apps: elements and components. Once you master them, you can create complex apps from small reusable pieces.</span></span>

> <span key="40df96d31dda48fa968a5ec07a482a50"><span offset-key="40df96d31dda48fa968a5ec07a482a50:0">TipThis guide is designed for people who prefer learning concepts step by step. If you prefer to learn by doing, check out our practical tutorial. You might find this guide and the tutorial complementary to each other.</span></span>

<span key="856ea20882a84ec79cf58543f90fdb17"><span offset-key="856ea20882a84ec79cf58543f90fdb17:0">This is the first chapter in a step-by-step guide about main React concepts. You can find a list of all its chapters in the navigation sidebar. If you're reading this from a mobile device, you can access the navigation by pressing the button in the bottom right corner of your screen.</span></span>

<span key="d32b2281eca348f4b906612442c9496b"><span offset-key="d32b2281eca348f4b906612442c9496b:0">Every chapter in this guide builds on the knowledge introduced in earlier chapters. </span>**You can learn most of React by reading the "Main Concepts" guide chapters in the order they appear in the sidebar.**<span offset-key="d32b2281eca348f4b906612442c9496b:2"> For example, </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/introducing-jsx.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a5956a471d524f08b6c6041a03fe7e1c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="0d6ab796291143789589590f3ee29fc5"><span data-offset-key="0d6ab796291143789589590f3ee29fc5:0">"Introducing JSX"</span></span></span></a><span key="fa86797413414cccb721bcce7346fe5a"><span offset-key="fa86797413414cccb721bcce7346fe5a:0"> is the next chapter after this one.</span></span>

# 

<span key="9e764996deaf4bd7a98d831b8c5f4bbc"><span offset-key="9e764996deaf4bd7a98d831b8c5f4bbc:0">Knowledge Level Assumptions</span></span>

<span key="defbf81c5aa9488da5077ec1afe070d9"><span offset-key="defbf81c5aa9488da5077ec1afe070d9:0">React is a JavaScript library, and so we'll assume you have a basic understanding of the JavaScript language. </span>**If you don't feel very confident, we recommend**<span offset-key="defbf81c5aa9488da5077ec1afe070d9:2"> </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/A_re-introduction_to_JavaScript" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="91f34a523fbb4b29bda279e45b38a3a2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="27003ce0f0014ab59ba523a9213a4894"><strong>going through a JavaScript tutorial</strong></span></span></a><span key="55ef0c4d9edc44df9071f3f6ea0a73d0"><span offset-key="55ef0c4d9edc44df9071f3f6ea0a73d0:0"> </span>**to check your knowledge level**<span offset-key="55ef0c4d9edc44df9071f3f6ea0a73d0:2"> and enable you to follow along this guide without getting lost. It might take you between 30 minutes and an hour, but as a result you won't have to feel like you're learning both React and JavaScript at the same time.</span></span>

> <span key="f32a7727f1f34f58962f1e86cd35e794"><span offset-key="f32a7727f1f34f58962f1e86cd35e794:0">NoteThis guide occasionally uses some newer JavaScript syntax in the examples. If you haven't worked with JavaScript in the last few years, these three points should get you most of the way.</span></span>

# 

<span key="5f3b6ee0b2624414bf19aa040e3b05af">**Introducing JSX**</span>

# 

<span key="cb486aeda6c847479dc3c4480156738a"><span offset-key="cb486aeda6c847479dc3c4480156738a:0">Consider this variable declaration:</span></span>

1

<span key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce"><span class="r-y7gyvo" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:0">const</span><span offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:1"> element </span><span class="r-11faab8" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:2">=</span><span offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:3"> </span><span class="r-dyg9za" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:4">&lt;</span><span class="r-qtrn9a" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:5">h1</span><span class="r-dyg9za" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:6">&gt;</span><span offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:7">Hello</span><span class="r-dyg9za" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:8">,</span><span offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:9"> world</span><span class="r-11faab8" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:10">!</span><span class="r-dyg9za" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:11">&lt;/</span><span class="r-qtrn9a" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:12">h1</span><span class="r-dyg9za" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:13">&gt;</span><span class="r-dyg9za" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="4411a9cfffe34d9386c1e3ac0b8cc3ce:14">;</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

<span key="2ec3095b2f10440c9405ac2d6ed2bea3"><span offset-key="2ec3095b2f10440c9405ac2d6ed2bea3:0">This funny tag syntax is neither a string nor HTML.</span></span>

<span key="5eb8158f4a644c4fa70a8cc4e14b57da"><span offset-key="5eb8158f4a644c4fa70a8cc4e14b57da:0">It is called JSX, and it is a syntax extension to JavaScript. We recommend using it with React to describe what the UI should look like. JSX may remind you of a template language, but it comes with the full power of JavaScript.</span></span>

<span key="a490a3ccdb5a470d84813174e78637b3"><span offset-key="a490a3ccdb5a470d84813174e78637b3:0">JSX produces React "elements". We will explore rendering them to the DOM in the </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/rendering-elements.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="6e6eb4718d71433f88426e414e30a312" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="f251b22934144e5f83bbcfaa77e4d2f3"><span data-offset-key="f251b22934144e5f83bbcfaa77e4d2f3:0">next section</span></span></span></a><span key="c04ce7bb188b462e9988d7a1980dd173"><span offset-key="c04ce7bb188b462e9988d7a1980dd173:0">. Below, you can find the basics of JSX necessary to get you started.</span></span>

# 

<span key="8ee46375026a4969b4bd84a6153c96bf"><span offset-key="8ee46375026a4969b4bd84a6153c96bf:0">Why JSX?</span></span>

<span key="dc328c98f99d4c89a95f716a8fa7a14a"><span offset-key="dc328c98f99d4c89a95f716a8fa7a14a:0">React embraces the fact that rendering logic is inherently coupled with other UI logic: how events are handled, how the state changes over time, and how the data is prepared for display.</span></span>

<span key="b91bc7c4791242b0945d5c3fd1120ec3"><span offset-key="b91bc7c4791242b0945d5c3fd1120ec3:0">Instead of artificially separating </span>*technologies*<span offset-key="b91bc7c4791242b0945d5c3fd1120ec3:2"> by putting markup and logic in separate files, React </span></span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_of_concerns" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ad830e73fa4f4ca883a7b459a795ae0c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="c34378c64f63425eb14a3ec60117c498"><span data-offset-key="c34378c64f63425eb14a3ec60117c498:0">separates </span><em>concerns</em></span></span></a><span key="1c8579789c67436d8cbfa44514abd64b"><span offset-key="1c8579789c67436d8cbfa44514abd64b:0"> with loosely coupled units called "components" that contain both. We will come back to components in a </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/components-and-props.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="474837a665fd496b88672413435216a9" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="81c5479165b2467dab84e93314accd98"><span data-offset-key="81c5479165b2467dab84e93314accd98:0">further section</span></span></span></a><span key="f1cb253b56f74119b37d4ef6450eae49"><span offset-key="f1cb253b56f74119b37d4ef6450eae49:0">, but if you're not yet comfortable putting markup in JS, </span></span><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x7cQ3mrcKaY" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="61361b45556d4786b766b574a4464bfc" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="3e17c013220047479544007ef7bf6b75"><span data-offset-key="3e17c013220047479544007ef7bf6b75:0">this talk</span></span></span></a><span key="db22c411d0bc410d91d8b0bac7a87ce2"><span offset-key="db22c411d0bc410d91d8b0bac7a87ce2:0"> might convince you otherwise.</span></span>

<span key="9f01e99d9e8d474baffbd8e524c70746"><span offset-key="9f01e99d9e8d474baffbd8e524c70746:0">React </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/react-without-jsx.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2d7f9c38272f4f92b88dab3e7e291263" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="2033a428f5154bc0a75ce284792bd447"><span data-offset-key="2033a428f5154bc0a75ce284792bd447:0">doesn't require</span></span></span></a><span key="b5b54da98777476791e924389802222f"><span offset-key="b5b54da98777476791e924389802222f:0"> using JSX, but most people find it helpful as a visual aid when working with UI inside the JavaScript code. It also allows React to show more useful error and warning messages.</span></span>

<span key="de0c927cf6ac401bb0f1a48ea17f1231"><span offset-key="de0c927cf6ac401bb0f1a48ea17f1231:0">With that out of the way, let's get started!</span></span>

<span key="89a849293a4049db823869a364fbf598"><span offset-key="89a849293a4049db823869a364fbf598:0">These objects are called "React elements". You can think of them as descriptions of what you want to see on the screen. React reads these objects and uses them to construct the DOM and keep it up to date.</span></span>

<span key="094954e8a38347109c02e17836d17592"><span offset-key="094954e8a38347109c02e17836d17592:0">We will explore rendering React elements to the DOM in the </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/rendering-elements.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="825e9320b5d247f2bb3b6b620fb334f7" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="db3cf38c102744ae83497d3b50faeea5"><span data-offset-key="db3cf38c102744ae83497d3b50faeea5:0">next section</span></span></span></a><span key="f332fabc9ed14d7eb20e123d698e36fa"><span offset-key="f332fabc9ed14d7eb20e123d698e36fa:0">.</span></span>

> <span key="20590cac945048ceba6ffa0f5af0f091"><span offset-key="20590cac945048ceba6ffa0f5af0f091:0">Tip:We recommend using the "Babel" language definition for your editor of choice so that both ES6 and JSX code is properly highlighted.</span></span>

# 

<span key="5144d857a8d34218bca0b9633bba31b5">**Rendering Elements**</span>

# 

<span key="f044cb6f70b04ceca472823c8984b04e"><span offset-key="f044cb6f70b04ceca472823c8984b04e:0">Elements are the smallest building blocks of React apps.</span></span>

<span key="c3ab09f80dee45eb944ba2861aafd742"><span offset-key="c3ab09f80dee45eb944ba2861aafd742:0">An element describes what you want to see on the screen:</span></span>

<span key="4a7bf0d886564f3592b619ac75d5322c">`const element = <h1>Hello, world</h1>;`</span>

<span key="c0ccd06b27f74fd6a569870564534076"><span offset-key="c0ccd06b27f74fd6a569870564534076:0">Unlike browser DOM elements, React elements are plain objects, and are cheap to create. React DOM takes care of updating the DOM to match the React elements.</span></span>

> <span key="3bede803d85943fd8854fa32598090c1"><span offset-key="3bede803d85943fd8854fa32598090c1:0">Note:One might confuse elements with a more widely known concept of "components". We will introduce components in the next section. Elements are what components are "made of", and we encourage you to read this section before jumping ahead.</span></span>

#

<span key="be7481196e1140f9a1b8d43e8382adbc"><span offset-key="be7481196e1140f9a1b8d43e8382adbc:0">Updating the Rendered Element</span></span>

<span key="82317c81ce7e478a890f90532facfd33"><span offset-key="82317c81ce7e478a890f90532facfd33:0">React elements are </span></span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immutable_object" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="52cd5d29c8714bd2b4f75188038ccb8d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="effded2dbbce42c18887f609a86b6b13"><span data-offset-key="effded2dbbce42c18887f609a86b6b13:0">immutable</span></span></span></a><span key="04c158288c704989a1584d37dbcd6888"><span offset-key="04c158288c704989a1584d37dbcd6888:0">. Once you create an element, you can't change its children or attributes. An element is like a single frame in a movie: it represents the UI at a certain point in time.</span></span>

<span key="6a03d820d7934c4784ab324c2041d74c"><span offset-key="6a03d820d7934c4784ab324c2041d74c:0">With our knowledge so far, the only way to update the UI is to create a new element, and pass it to </span>`[ReactDOM.render()](<https://reactjs.org/docs/react-dom.html#render>)`<span offset-key="6a03d820d7934c4784ab324c2041d74c:2">.</span></span>

<span key="18c6e6c2b6fb44e0b14c54ca4b4608c1"><span offset-key="18c6e6c2b6fb44e0b14c54ca4b4608c1:0">Consider this ticking clock example:</span></span>

<span key="7ce00b3a40d1406fbec1bd1931e2b1ad"><span offset-key="7ce00b3a40d1406fbec1bd1931e2b1ad:0">It calls </span>`[ReactDOM.render()](<https://reactjs.org/docs/react-dom.html#render>)`<span offset-key="7ce00b3a40d1406fbec1bd1931e2b1ad:2"> every second from a </span>`[setInterval()](<https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowTimers/setInterval>)`<span offset-key="7ce00b3a40d1406fbec1bd1931e2b1ad:4"> callback.</span></span>

> <span key="0a42c186ba404a56b8f28c895df7123b"><span offset-key="0a42c186ba404a56b8f28c895df7123b:0">Note:In practice, most React apps only call ReactDOM.render() once. In the next sections we will learn how such code gets encapsulated into stateful components.We recommend that you don't skip topics because they build on each other.</span></span>

# 

<span key="16af6e74d596402596770a571f32f52b"><span offset-key="16af6e74d596402596770a571f32f52b:0">React Only Updates What's Necessary</span></span>

<span key="fb798d2fe172433c8ae29dd8b2a08851"><span offset-key="fb798d2fe172433c8ae29dd8b2a08851:0">React DOM compares the element and its children to the previous one, and only applies the DOM updates necessary to bring the DOM to the desired state.</span></span>

<span key="9a97fe589c454889b6e1fd9de372d41a"><span offset-key="9a97fe589c454889b6e1fd9de372d41a:0">You can verify by inspecting the </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/redirect-to-codepen/rendering-elements/update-rendered-element" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3b9c728e9ca94152bab80c273f77b533" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="6dc512e61d8546b1a66c67bd8bac5724"><span data-offset-key="6dc512e61d8546b1a66c67bd8bac5724:0">last example</span></span></span></a><span key="2519e55bbaaf43ffa43175072a6a2999"><span offset-key="2519e55bbaaf43ffa43175072a6a2999:0"> with the browser tools:</span></span>

<span key="7101f45e8a454bc6bd15a5283fa941aa"><span offset-key="7101f45e8a454bc6bd15a5283fa941aa:0">https://reactjs.org/c158617ed7cc0eac8f58330e49e48224/granular-dom-updates.gif</span></span>

<span key="f915fad4787f4777a8eea65c865a9d08"><span offset-key="f915fad4787f4777a8eea65c865a9d08:0">Even though we create an element describing the whole UI tree on every tick, only the text node whose contents have changed gets updated by React DOM.</span></span>

<span key="538b497a4e064b87accf88a937a0a6aa"><span offset-key="538b497a4e064b87accf88a937a0a6aa:0">In our experience, thinking about how the UI should look at any given moment, rather than how to change it over time, eliminates a whole class of bugs.</span></span>

# 

<span key="81d79ebbacc8427ca95019ac06633c65">**Components and Props**</span>

# 

<span key="d8489dc054d649dd978bd5ee45378415"><span offset-key="d8489dc054d649dd978bd5ee45378415:0">Components let you split the UI into independent, reusable pieces, and think about each piece in isolation. This page provides an introduction to the idea of components. You can find a </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/react-component.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="30fcfccef68d47298c99aa86edc65903" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="2cc98bc223894810a1fb0a8220487215"><span data-offset-key="2cc98bc223894810a1fb0a8220487215:0">detailed component API reference here</span></span></span></a><span key="0d3066883e224f3f95fe97b57373ffc3"><span offset-key="0d3066883e224f3f95fe97b57373ffc3:0">.</span></span>

<span key="aef8577c5021439aa04e4b9b0180ea96"><span offset-key="aef8577c5021439aa04e4b9b0180ea96:0">Conceptually, components are like JavaScript functions. They accept arbitrary inputs (called "props") and return React elements describing what should appear on the screen.</span></span>

# 

<span key="65d84fd4d2a944f099799f8768488b53"><span offset-key="65d84fd4d2a944f099799f8768488b53:0">Function and Class Components</span></span>

<span key="5ed5c75eab4a4305b5fd230fd34eee0d"><span offset-key="5ed5c75eab4a4305b5fd230fd34eee0d:0">The simplest way to define a component is to write a JavaScript function:</span></span>

1

<span key="d6d49b2026e44242952b4fffe1ce0aef"><span offset-key="d6d49b2026e44242952b4fffe1ce0aef:0">This function is a valid React component because it accepts a single "props" (which stands for properties) object argument with data and returns a React element. <span key="3ea22187582f4409a51c8f6fec1a76f3"><span offset-key="3ea22187582f4409a51c8f6fec1a76f3:0">Let's recap what happens in this example:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="7c2524335a9243ba9dda4da80a5ac408"><span offset-key="7c2524335a9243ba9dda4da80a5ac408:0">We call </span>`ReactDOM.render()`<span offset-key="7c2524335a9243ba9dda4da80a5ac408:2"> with the </span>`<Welcome name="Sara" />`<span offset-key="7c2524335a9243ba9dda4da80a5ac408:4"> element.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="50927bb661044517a46f8d06d2c3c0ac"><span offset-key="50927bb661044517a46f8d06d2c3c0ac:0">React calls the </span>`Welcome`<span offset-key="50927bb661044517a46f8d06d2c3c0ac:2"> component with </span>`{name: 'Sara'}`<span offset-key="50927bb661044517a46f8d06d2c3c0ac:4"> as the props.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="188ba762a2fb4fbf8843ba1ccf30c618"><span offset-key="188ba762a2fb4fbf8843ba1ccf30c618:0">Our </span>`Welcome`<span offset-key="188ba762a2fb4fbf8843ba1ccf30c618:2"> component returns a </span>`<h1>Hello, Sara</h1>`<span offset-key="188ba762a2fb4fbf8843ba1ccf30c618:4"> element as the result.</span></span>

4.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">4.</span>
    <span key="38662dd1684f47c5ada71dd76bc12bfb"><span offset-key="38662dd1684f47c5ada71dd76bc12bfb:0">React DOM efficiently updates the DOM to match </span>`<h1>Hello, Sara</h1>`<span offset-key="38662dd1684f47c5ada71dd76bc12bfb:2">.</span></span>

> <span key="c4d015a424bb4366a9b585392b41b96a"><span offset-key="c4d015a424bb4366a9b585392b41b96a:0">Note: Always start component names with a capital letter.React treats components starting with lowercase letters as DOM tags. For example, represents an HTML div tag, but represents a component and requires Welcome to be in </span></span><a href="http://scope.to" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="d791faa77e634787a2e9c8c2195d3a4b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="5d9eb87cf62e4975b53e6e44cb22fcb2"><span data-offset-key="5d9eb87cf62e4975b53e6e44cb22fcb2:0">scope.To</span></span></span></a><span key="3909abb3af624cfcaccee581c92783f7"><span offset-key="3909abb3af624cfcaccee581c92783f7:0"> learn more about the reasoning behind this convention, please read JSX In Depth.</span></span>

# 

<span key="357bf5bff3e54c53943d443c8503c58a"><span offset-key="357bf5bff3e54c53943d443c8503c58a:0">Composing Components</span></span>

<span key="6cc1480cbed34656a3de4030f1cf64b8"><span offset-key="6cc1480cbed34656a3de4030f1cf64b8:0">Components can refer to other components in their output. This lets us use the same component abstraction for any level of detail. A button, a form, a dialog, a screen: in React apps, all those are commonly expressed as components.</span></span>

<span key="2cda2e58a987441b8991193e7f7c5b61"><span offset-key="2cda2e58a987441b8991193e7f7c5b61:0">For example, we can create an </span>`App`<span offset-key="2cda2e58a987441b8991193e7f7c5b61:2"> component that renders </span>`Welcome`<span offset-key="2cda2e58a987441b8991193e7f7c5b61:4"> many times:</span></span>

1

# 

<span key="ce09f7dd8fa447e3b3e7934fde257f36"><span offset-key="ce09f7dd8fa447e3b3e7934fde257f36:0">Adding Lifecycle Methods to a Class</span></span>

<span key="671fd9425f4848199de903f5d1e6a5c1"><span offset-key="671fd9425f4848199de903f5d1e6a5c1:0">In applications with many components, it's very important to free up resources taken by the components when they are destroyed.</span></span>

<span key="125e1902748444b881f471c4b072fe75"><span offset-key="125e1902748444b881f471c4b072fe75:0">We want to </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowTimers/setInterval" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="e092bee04319484e9149ded1d25a13c3" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="e33d2395ea8b4b3e8be7a9ca10c54ca4"><span data-offset-key="e33d2395ea8b4b3e8be7a9ca10c54ca4:0">set up a timer</span></span></span></a><span key="340a3ab0b7414d83a8ead1a28886db36"><span offset-key="340a3ab0b7414d83a8ead1a28886db36:0"> whenever the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="340a3ab0b7414d83a8ead1a28886db36:2"> is rendered to the DOM for the first time. This is called "mounting" in React.</span></span>

<span key="25358b2d4512456ebfac25a250671992"><span offset-key="25358b2d4512456ebfac25a250671992:0">We also want to </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowTimers/clearInterval" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="455fe26c87e943bdbcee30bf8045c02e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="5dc654bd62954b51ace013d989d06821"><span data-offset-key="5dc654bd62954b51ace013d989d06821:0">clear that timer</span></span></span></a><span key="895dfefe515a4836a0fd332a196e2e13"><span offset-key="895dfefe515a4836a0fd332a196e2e13:0"> whenever the DOM produced by the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="895dfefe515a4836a0fd332a196e2e13:2"> is removed. This is called "unmounting" in React.</span></span>

<span key="071d5d63849049a1a1bb3a6899458ba2"><span offset-key="071d5d63849049a1a1bb3a6899458ba2:0">We can declare special methods on the component class to run some code when a component mounts and unmounts:</span></span>

1

<span key="a4902a859e3e4ca6b33793ada8f08913"><span offset-key="a4902a859e3e4ca6b33793ada8f08913:0">The </span>`componentDidMount()`<span offset-key="a4902a859e3e4ca6b33793ada8f08913:2"> method runs after the component output has been rendered to the DOM. This is a good place to set up a timer:</span></span>

<span key="61d5b480235e4ee786c06ce51ae9c19a"><span offset-key="61d5b480235e4ee786c06ce51ae9c19a:0">Note how we save the timer ID right on </span>`this`<span offset-key="61d5b480235e4ee786c06ce51ae9c19a:2"> (</span>`this.timerID`<span offset-key="61d5b480235e4ee786c06ce51ae9c19a:4">).</span></span>

<span key="02d2bb6fd3b8411c865e44296a0df364"><span offset-key="02d2bb6fd3b8411c865e44296a0df364:0">While </span>`this.props`<span offset-key="02d2bb6fd3b8411c865e44296a0df364:2"> is set up by React itself and </span>`this.state`<span offset-key="02d2bb6fd3b8411c865e44296a0df364:4"> has a special meaning, you are free to add additional fields to the class manually if you need to store something that doesn't participate in the data flow (like a timer ID).</span></span>

<span key="21909c81e86841359e857e74ff51d4cc"><span offset-key="21909c81e86841359e857e74ff51d4cc:0">We will tear down the timer in the </span>`componentWillUnmount()`<span offset-key="21909c81e86841359e857e74ff51d4cc:2"> lifecycle method:</span></span>

1

2

<span key="12d69c5f34744b91af1930b3492c1d8f"><span offset-key="12d69c5f34744b91af1930b3492c1d8f:0"> clearInterval(this.timerID); }</span></span>

<span key="86d63d2f03b84d81bd6020c3c23daee6"><span offset-key="86d63d2f03b84d81bd6020c3c23daee6:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://codepen.io/gaearon/pen/amqdNA?editors=0010" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b6415a8a768e4f21816fb44e6093e392" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="d15de9337b30454b8e4bdf9ceece1517"><strong>Try it on CodePen</strong></span></span></a><span key="7f061e70222d41fc8f992e673c6171c8"><span offset-key="7f061e70222d41fc8f992e673c6171c8:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="b4d680dbf9c048ef9c9c64d01f9eb1cd"><span offset-key="b4d680dbf9c048ef9c9c64d01f9eb1cd:0">Now the clock ticks every second.</span></span>

<span key="4737e1b9b2bb406e808e50b5d9570706"><span offset-key="4737e1b9b2bb406e808e50b5d9570706:0">Let's quickly recap what's going on and the order in which the methods are called:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="72f891ea0637407d80bec3187a6ed4cc"><span offset-key="72f891ea0637407d80bec3187a6ed4cc:0">When </span>`<Clock />`<span offset-key="72f891ea0637407d80bec3187a6ed4cc:2"> is passed to </span>`ReactDOM.render()`<span offset-key="72f891ea0637407d80bec3187a6ed4cc:4">, React calls the constructor of the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="72f891ea0637407d80bec3187a6ed4cc:6"> component. Since </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="72f891ea0637407d80bec3187a6ed4cc:8"> needs to display the current time, it initializes </span>`this.state`<span offset-key="72f891ea0637407d80bec3187a6ed4cc:10"> with an object including the current time. We will later update this state.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="0c4315f4acce41f8926734856785c2de"><span offset-key="0c4315f4acce41f8926734856785c2de:0">React then calls the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="0c4315f4acce41f8926734856785c2de:2"> component's </span>`render()`<span offset-key="0c4315f4acce41f8926734856785c2de:4"> method. This is how React learns what should be displayed on the screen. React then updates the DOM to match the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="0c4315f4acce41f8926734856785c2de:6">'s render output.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="1e8bf29fe9bf4707a5abb4b9ddaca11e"><span offset-key="1e8bf29fe9bf4707a5abb4b9ddaca11e:0">When the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="1e8bf29fe9bf4707a5abb4b9ddaca11e:2"> output is inserted in the DOM, React calls the </span>`componentDidMount()`<span offset-key="1e8bf29fe9bf4707a5abb4b9ddaca11e:4"> lifecycle method. Inside it, the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="1e8bf29fe9bf4707a5abb4b9ddaca11e:6"> component asks the browser to set up a timer to call the component's </span>`tick()`<span offset-key="1e8bf29fe9bf4707a5abb4b9ddaca11e:8"> method once a second.</span></span>

4.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">4.</span>
    <span key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e"><span offset-key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e:0">Every second the browser calls the </span>`tick()`<span offset-key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e:2"> method. Inside it, the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e:4"> component schedules a UI update by calling </span>`setState()`<span offset-key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e:6"> with an object containing the current time. Thanks to the </span>`setState()`<span offset-key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e:8"> call, React knows the state has changed, and calls the </span>`render()`<span offset-key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e:10"> method again to learn what should be on the screen. This time, </span>`this.state.date`<span offset-key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e:12"> in the </span>`render()`<span offset-key="b04a31bdbe5f478c98e260cdfd4cf19e:14"> method will be different, and so the render output will include the updated time. React updates the DOM accordingly.</span></span>

5.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">5.</span>
    <span key="3f5f67416349461ea3601750052b5ed7"><span offset-key="3f5f67416349461ea3601750052b5ed7:0">If the </span>`Clock`<span offset-key="3f5f67416349461ea3601750052b5ed7:2"> component is ever removed from the DOM, React calls the </span>`componentWillUnmount()`<span offset-key="3f5f67416349461ea3601750052b5ed7:4"> lifecycle method so the timer is stopped.</span></span>

# 

<span key="7d907dca5fd64379a9ba633e82eb8e58"><span offset-key="7d907dca5fd64379a9ba633e82eb8e58:0">Using State Correctly</span></span>

<span key="3f7cd63603f947b4b14ce4e77577ad84"><span offset-key="3f7cd63603f947b4b14ce4e77577ad84:0">There are three things you should know about </span>`setState()`<span offset-key="3f7cd63603f947b4b14ce4e77577ad84:2">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="175b311b41194996963e0c8e71d435eb"><span offset-key="175b311b41194996963e0c8e71d435eb:0">Do Not Modify State Directly</span></span>

<span key="fea96fcb153a43539fc92b9e79886a56"><span offset-key="fea96fcb153a43539fc92b9e79886a56:0">For example, this will not re-render a component:</span></span>

# 

<span key="2bfb6f1ad7d544f7a3e0d131b8715c8e"><span offset-key="2bfb6f1ad7d544f7a3e0d131b8715c8e:0">State Updates May Be Asynchronous</span></span>

<span key="b3f832ea4e604e5f953f81ad1e56ebed"><span offset-key="b3f832ea4e604e5f953f81ad1e56ebed:0">React may batch multiple </span>`setState()`<span offset-key="b3f832ea4e604e5f953f81ad1e56ebed:2"> calls into a single update for performance.</span></span>

<span key="405685bdf00246ecbd2f2d12c3348001"><span offset-key="405685bdf00246ecbd2f2d12c3348001:0">Because </span>`this.props`<span offset-key="405685bdf00246ecbd2f2d12c3348001:2"> and </span>`this.state`<span offset-key="405685bdf00246ecbd2f2d12c3348001:4"> may be updated asynchronously, you should not rely on their values for calculating the next state.</span></span>

<span key="9a77dcd5da48471d99d8af74ebbd73e3"><span offset-key="9a77dcd5da48471d99d8af74ebbd73e3:0">For example, this code may fail to update the counter:</span></span>

<span key="cef822f164c34061803405bd3773d361"><span offset-key="cef822f164c34061803405bd3773d361:0">The Data Flows Down</span></span>

<span key="58e25a17eeda4cf29083431d9490486a">**Handling Events**</span>

# 

<span key="a921be4253c742a8b7894ec1dde682eb"><span offset-key="a921be4253c742a8b7894ec1dde682eb:0">Handling events with React elements is very similar to handling events on DOM elements. There are some syntax differences:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="11044beb1d9e487fae1453fbe717de61"><span offset-key="11044beb1d9e487fae1453fbe717de61:0">React events are named using camelCase, rather than lowercase.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a6d02b452df1450f8bf817556dd63faa"><span offset-key="a6d02b452df1450f8bf817556dd63faa:0">With JSX you pass a function as the event handler, rather than a string.</span></span>

<span key="8f4dd7cc369c4bdba225e7a270df45cf"><span offset-key="8f4dd7cc369c4bdba225e7a270df45cf:0">For example, the HTML:</span></span>

1

<span key="0080674aaacb4ca0a83ae2e96528fbd3"><span offset-key="0080674aaacb4ca0a83ae2e96528fbd3:0">&lt;button onclick="activateLasers()"></span></span>

2

3

<span key="3406a42a797445f9a2013531d0f41b0d"><span offset-key="3406a42a797445f9a2013531d0f41b0d:0">&lt;button onClick={activateLasers}> Activate Lasers</span></span>

<span key="dac6ac76c6444be3bee8d2f370b5bf6c"><span offset-key="dac6ac76c6444be3bee8d2f370b5bf6c:0">Another difference is that you cannot return </span>`false`<span offset-key="dac6ac76c6444be3bee8d2f370b5bf6c:2"> to prevent default behavior in React. You must call </span>`preventDefault`<span offset-key="dac6ac76c6444be3bee8d2f370b5bf6c:4"> explicitly. For example, with plain HTML, to prevent the default form behavior of submitting, you can write:</span></span>

1

<span key="96eebb07aeda429aa73adccb0dbbdaaa"><span offset-key="96eebb07aeda429aa73adccb0dbbdaaa:0">&lt;form onsubmit="console.log('You clicked submit.'); return false">&lt;button type="submit">Submit&lt;/button>&lt;/form></span></span>

React defines these synthetic events according to the </span></span><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="0df43917ef1d4752a16ed9efe17b5228" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="22d58388d17644dda58e299b162e1761"><span data-offset-key="22d58388d17644dda58e299b162e1761:0">W3C spec</span></span></span></a><span key="c778e2957ed843e4821ffc8936482fd1"><span offset-key="c778e2957ed843e4821ffc8936482fd1:0">, so you don't need to worry about cross-browser compatibility. <span key="2f8fb66992194d68ae73363dbf9d2a7f"><span offset-key="2f8fb66992194d68ae73363dbf9d2a7f:0">When using React, you generally don't need to call </span>`addEventListener`<span offset-key="2f8fb66992194d68ae73363dbf9d2a7f:2"> to add listeners to a DOM element after it is created. <span key="8d53be6f649344db92a36344a9079ec2"><span offset-key="8d53be6f649344db92a36344a9079ec2:0">The problem with this syntax is that a different callback is created each time the </span>`LoggingButton`<span offset-key="8d53be6f649344db92a36344a9079ec2:2"> renders. We generally recommend binding in the constructor or using the class fields syntax, to avoid this sort of performance problem.</span></span>

# 

<span key="22d680793b244daa955745f1d85a8daf"><span offset-key="22d680793b244daa955745f1d85a8daf:0">Passing Arguments to Event Handlers</span></span>

<span key="5187d230480f46c9a2b05674878d62ae"><span offset-key="5187d230480f46c9a2b05674878d62ae:0">Inside a loop, it is common to want to pass an extra parameter to an event handler. For example, if </span>`id`<span offset-key="5187d230480f46c9a2b05674878d62ae:2"> is the row ID, either of the following would work:</span></span>

<span key="3dfe4332af384a4da0370d7fd5fd2ce4">`<button onClick={(e) => this.deleteRow(id, e)}>Delete Row</button><button onClick={this.deleteRow.bind(this, id)}>Delete Row</button>`</span>

<span key="aa0dde2706324b1589922b09beda325c"><span offset-key="aa0dde2706324b1589922b09beda325c:0">The above two lines are equivalent, and use </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/Arrow_functions" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a9a426cb61664a989aac4f1f52ac24e6" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="6a4144cdaba54ed2804c566908d82248"><span data-offset-key="6a4144cdaba54ed2804c566908d82248:0">arrow functions</span></span></span></a><span key="23abf1c7a44243b4b58b72deabd6f7d6"><span offset-key="23abf1c7a44243b4b58b72deabd6f7d6:0"> and </span>`[Function.prototype.bind](<https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_objects/Function/bind>)`<span offset-key="23abf1c7a44243b4b58b72deabd6f7d6:2"> respectively.</span></span>

<span key="72add1de9aae4878bcee6625dec06544"><span offset-key="72add1de9aae4878bcee6625dec06544:0">In both cases, the </span>`e`<span offset-key="72add1de9aae4878bcee6625dec06544:2"> argument representing the React event will be passed as a second argument after the ID. With an arrow function, we have to pass it explicitly, but with </span>`bind`<span offset-key="72add1de9aae4878bcee6625dec06544:4"> any further arguments are automatically forwarded.</span></span>

<span key="d326ecd426ac4dd6a5e8b073c03017cf"><span offset-key="d326ecd426ac4dd6a5e8b073c03017cf:0">Conditional rendering in React works the same way conditions work in JavaScript. This can negatively impact performance and may cause issues with component state. <span key="06ce2204aa1e44e4811f971f163f13bb">**Forms**</span>

# 

<span key="e482837d59c44075a5edab1ee99ab412"><span offset-key="e482837d59c44075a5edab1ee99ab412:0">HTML form elements work a bit differently from other DOM elements in React, because form elements naturally keep some internal state. For example, this form in plain HTML accepts a single name:</span></span>

1

<span key="25a1d67ab4c544d4b638997c427283a5"><span offset-key="25a1d67ab4c544d4b638997c427283a5:0">&lt;form>&lt;label></span></span>

3

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7c43aa1640f44a40af91f573b60eac83"><span offset-key="7c43aa1640f44a40af91f573b60eac83:0">This form has the default HTML form behavior of browsing to a new page when the user submits the form. If you want this behavior in React, it just works. But in most cases, it's convenient to have a JavaScript function that handles the submission of the form and has access to the data that the user entered into the form. The standard way to achieve this is with a technique called "controlled components".</span></span>

# 

<span key="4299f378ba5348a498a272c5e32f11c8"><span offset-key="4299f378ba5348a498a272c5e32f11c8:0">Controlled Components</span></span>

<span key="f364773aa75f4054b9ae5cb039e0ae7f"><span offset-key="f364773aa75f4054b9ae5cb039e0ae7f:0">In HTML, form elements such as </span>`<input>`<span offset-key="f364773aa75f4054b9ae5cb039e0ae7f:2">, </span>`<textarea>`<span offset-key="f364773aa75f4054b9ae5cb039e0ae7f:4">, and </span>`<select>`<span offset-key="f364773aa75f4054b9ae5cb039e0ae7f:6"> typically maintain their own state and update it based on user input. In React, mutable state is typically kept in the state property of components, and only updated with </span>`[setState()](<https://reactjs.org/docs/react-component.html#setstate>)`<span offset-key="f364773aa75f4054b9ae5cb039e0ae7f:8">.</span></span>

<span key="be0a2fa116814f6c92e08794bc2a80ee"><span offset-key="be0a2fa116814f6c92e08794bc2a80ee:0">We can combine the two by making the React state be the "single source of truth". Then the React component that renders a form also controls what happens in that form on subsequent user input. An input form element whose value is controlled by React in this way is called a "controlled component".</span></span>

<span key="ea2b39c3d8d6432e91a2016eb1baf62b"><span offset-key="ea2b39c3d8d6432e91a2016eb1baf62b:0">For example, if we want to make the previous example log the name when it is submitted, we can write the form as a controlled component:</span></span>

<span key="b5a2392afd0e4ebcb324363aa615af8f"><span offset-key="b5a2392afd0e4ebcb324363aa615af8f:0">Since the </span>`value`<span offset-key="b5a2392afd0e4ebcb324363aa615af8f:2"> attribute is set on our form element, the displayed value will always be </span>`this.state.value`<span offset-key="b5a2392afd0e4ebcb324363aa615af8f:4">, making the React state the source of truth. Since </span>`handleChange`<span offset-key="b5a2392afd0e4ebcb324363aa615af8f:6"> runs on every keystroke to update the React state, the displayed value will update as the user types.</span></span>

<span key="1c893115b69a4c5492ba71acbac85a9f"><span offset-key="1c893115b69a4c5492ba71acbac85a9f:0">With a controlled component, the input's value is always driven by the React state. While this means you have to type a bit more code, you can now pass the value to other UI elements too, or reset it from other event handlers.</span></span>

# 

<span key="0dff1b6c55a04fc99ade00c5972fe5d4"><span offset-key="0dff1b6c55a04fc99ade00c5972fe5d4:0">The textarea Tag</span></span>

<span key="c88f4b54c8664e8ea8844e54f169158b"><span offset-key="c88f4b54c8664e8ea8844e54f169158b:0">&lt;textarea></span></span>

<span key="30608c25398749e0b560a753e9efcf22"><span offset-key="30608c25398749e0b560a753e9efcf22:0">&lt;/textarea></span></span>

# 

<span key="22f4fb5f500b4cb4bbe23f3b4c5c4cf9"><span offset-key="22f4fb5f500b4cb4bbe23f3b4c5c4cf9:0">The file input Tag</span></span>

<span key="c3bf5ae9f4734b12a7e0d214c8e8f8fd"><span offset-key="c3bf5ae9f4734b12a7e0d214c8e8f8fd:0">In HTML, an </span>`<input type="file">`<span offset-key="c3bf5ae9f4734b12a7e0d214c8e8f8fd:2"> lets the user choose one or more files from their device storage to be uploaded to a server or manipulated by JavaScript via the </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/File/Using_files_from_web_applications" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="967a914e7b6544c287bb1de00034baf5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="214004f26070499db5c9d74c1728f2cf"><span data-offset-key="214004f26070499db5c9d74c1728f2cf:0">File API</span></span></span></a><span key="e43272547adb4d7292253060300aad2a"><span offset-key="e43272547adb4d7292253060300aad2a:0">.</span></span>

<span key="3948fd50b86344e8a691322286c50ace">`<input type="file" />`</span>

<span key="22ca5178c0d74431b32fa157bb1c1dd3"><span offset-key="22ca5178c0d74431b32fa157bb1c1dd3:0">Because its value is read-only, it is an </span>**uncontrolled**<span offset-key="22ca5178c0d74431b32fa157bb1c1dd3:2"> component in React. It is discussed together with other uncontrolled components </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/uncontrolled-components.html#the-file-input-tag" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="0023dbb1092946e7aad27f984a4446f9" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="9641c43501814ed4993366207286b9e2"><span data-offset-key="9641c43501814ed4993366207286b9e2:0">later in the documentation</span></span></span></a><span key="8809014646474d168ed496028417a373"><span offset-key="8809014646474d168ed496028417a373:0">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="29a628560f3d4c34afa260ad05c93152"><span offset-key="29a628560f3d4c34afa260ad05c93152:0">Alternatives to Controlled Components</span></span>

<span key="d860dd62c2e74ce889c67a4f639234cb"><span offset-key="d860dd62c2e74ce889c67a4f639234cb:0">It can sometimes be tedious to use controlled components, because you need to write an event handler for every way your data can change and pipe all of the input state through a React component. This can become particularly annoying when you are converting a preexisting codebase to React, or integrating a React application with a non-React library. In these situations, you might want to check out </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/uncontrolled-components.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3f3287c4485d4a1593ad72a51a3ee987" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="a1fd2180d6fe4afdbf6b1c8dfe2ff29b"><span data-offset-key="a1fd2180d6fe4afdbf6b1c8dfe2ff29b:0">uncontrolled components</span></span></span></a><span key="0b27f2eb34834040bff8ed46e4e6335d"><span offset-key="0b27f2eb34834040bff8ed46e4e6335d:0">, an alternative technique for implementing input forms.</span></span>

# 

<span key="3cf3d04ce9ba4f929302b8d9066cae79"><span offset-key="3cf3d04ce9ba4f929302b8d9066cae79:0">Fully-Fledged Solutions</span></span>

<span key="280a3913c8ec4bdbb7bf11f96ca8dce6"><span offset-key="280a3913c8ec4bdbb7bf11f96ca8dce6:0">If you're looking for a complete solution including validation, keeping track of the visited fields, and handling form submission, </span></span><a href="https://jaredpalmer.com/formik" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="974dc348d6b24451954f0bef8e2d1c2a" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="0899ab291e1b408eb9f870d0872fb183"><span data-offset-key="0899ab291e1b408eb9f870d0872fb183:0">Formik</span></span></span></a><span key="e801248db6634f4ab5ee93dec3bbc575"><span offset-key="e801248db6634f4ab5ee93dec3bbc575:0"> is one of the popular choices. However, it is built on the same principles of controlled components and managing state --- so don't neglect to learn them.</span></span>

<span key="e2fefa17abc246449a0bef08d7cb8b91"><span offset-key="e2fefa17abc246449a0bef08d7cb8b91:0">In React, sharing state is accomplished by moving it up to the closest common ancestor of the components that need it. We will remove the local state from the </span>`TemperatureInput`<span offset-key="e2fefa17abc246449a0bef08d7cb8b91:2"> and move it into the </span>`Calculator`<span offset-key="e2fefa17abc246449a0bef08d7cb8b91:4"> instead.</span></span>

It can instruct them both to have values that are consistent with each other. Since the props of both </span>`TemperatureInput`<span offset-key="e47907b6e502419696ab526d2ac77968:4"> components are coming from the same parent </span>`Calculator`<span offset-key="e47907b6e502419696ab526d2ac77968:6"> component, the two inputs will always be in sync.</span></span>

Its props, including </span>`onTemperatureChange`<span offset-key="06b6d885f6de4002b729da3bf77fac4f:8">, were provided by its parent component, the </span>`Calculator`<span offset-key="06b6d885f6de4002b729da3bf77fac4f:10">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="24e7e6ec0267456bb2da5b3f692f384e"><span offset-key="24e7e6ec0267456bb2da5b3f692f384e:0">Lessons Learned</span></span>

<span key="13774ffc223449299f7e1334b2ccd684"><span offset-key="13774ffc223449299f7e1334b2ccd684:0">There should be a single "source of truth" for any data that changes in a React application. Usually, the state is first added to the component that needs it for rendering. Then, if other components also need it, you can lift it up to their closest common ancestor. Instead of trying to sync the state between different components, you should rely on the </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/state-and-lifecycle.html#the-data-flows-down" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="238ef15d92ba4742aab372b48e49e32b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="bef3a927ea5341a2b5d0e89c445d44df"><span data-offset-key="bef3a927ea5341a2b5d0e89c445d44df:0">top-down data flow</span></span></span></a><span key="0a4db91c71694c0283fad8477e9b62f2"><span offset-key="0a4db91c71694c0283fad8477e9b62f2:0">.</span></span>

<span key="ef18d28fa87643f697b2329ded039368"><span offset-key="ef18d28fa87643f697b2329ded039368:0">Lifting state involves writing more "boilerplate" code than two-way binding approaches, but as a benefit, it takes less work to find and isolate bugs. Since any state "lives" in some component and that component alone can change it, the surface area for bugs is greatly reduced. Additionally, you can implement any custom logic to reject or transform user input.</span></span>

<span key="81a67b43c37b41919b4289d32c5343b2"><span offset-key="81a67b43c37b41919b4289d32c5343b2:0">If something can be derived from either props or state, it probably shouldn't be in the state. For example, instead of storing both </span>`celsiusValue`<span offset-key="81a67b43c37b41919b4289d32c5343b2:2"> and </span>`fahrenheitValue`<span offset-key="81a67b43c37b41919b4289d32c5343b2:4">, we store just the last edited </span>`temperature`<span offset-key="81a67b43c37b41919b4289d32c5343b2:6"> and its </span>`scale`<span offset-key="81a67b43c37b41919b4289d32c5343b2:8">. The value of the other input can always be calculated from them in the </span>`render()`<span offset-key="81a67b43c37b41919b4289d32c5343b2:10"> method. This lets us clear or apply rounding to the other field without losing any precision in the user input.</span></span>

<span key="5576829a72fa4e2fbb11bd63d578b9dd"><span offset-key="5576829a72fa4e2fbb11bd63d578b9dd:0">When you see something wrong in the UI, you can use </span></span><a href="https://github.com/facebook/react/tree/main/packages/react-devtools" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f797ddac2e8f4a54af2a468c24000008" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="8a65265d07374146a108b486b15a5dfc"><span data-offset-key="8a65265d07374146a108b486b15a5dfc:0">React Developer Tools</span></span></span></a><span key="a0526424c8c2427383b3b9c480bd3128"><span offset-key="a0526424c8c2427383b3b9c480bd3128:0"> to inspect the props and move up the tree until you find the component responsible for updating the state. This lets you trace the bugs to their source:</span></span>

<span key="d7294f2ccfd642b48eb80657b08e2610"><span offset-key="d7294f2ccfd642b48eb80657b08e2610:0">https://reactjs.org/ef94afc3447d75cdc245c77efb0d63be/react-devtools-state.gif</span></span>

# 

<span key="8faa207a3dad45ab9305b0f4675aad34">**Composition vs Inheritance**</span>

# 

<span key="13f2a9b236364791a931fdb7cd8c0301"><span offset-key="13f2a9b236364791a931fdb7cd8c0301:0">React has a powerful composition model, and we recommend using composition instead of inheritance to reuse code between components.</span></span>

<span key="ab9fced4e0244f39969392a71bbe8ede"><span offset-key="ab9fced4e0244f39969392a71bbe8ede:0">In this section, we will consider a few problems where developers new to React often reach for inheritance, and show how we can solve them with composition.</span></span>

# 

<span key="cd3a9e4af54c4c2081be1bc507391076"><span offset-key="cd3a9e4af54c4c2081be1bc507391076:0">Containment</span></span>

<span key="b442da08476748e38fd7cbd7529b4f5c"><span offset-key="b442da08476748e38fd7cbd7529b4f5c:0">Some components don't know their children ahead of time. <span key="60f92f5f8d15433480dcafca3cedc5a2"><span offset-key="60f92f5f8d15433480dcafca3cedc5a2:0">We recommend that such components use the special </span>`children`<span offset-key="60f92f5f8d15433480dcafca3cedc5a2:2"> prop to pass children elements directly into their output:</span></span>

<span key="bab3222397824e3485a0a39671640580"><span offset-key="bab3222397824e3485a0a39671640580:0">While this is less common, sometimes you might need multiple "holes" in a component. # 

<span key="41ab69a529894ebe98a8c55446ffae25"><span offset-key="41ab69a529894ebe98a8c55446ffae25:0">So What About Inheritance?</span></span>

<span key="c657a660f1964c0fa3fa5a0c5febe529"><span offset-key="c657a660f1964c0fa3fa5a0c5febe529:0">At Facebook, we use React in thousands of components, and we haven't found any use cases where we would recommend creating component inheritance hierarchies.</span></span>

<span key="46ac4422c9ac4a778c3a081f5d37a6a1"><span offset-key="46ac4422c9ac4a778c3a081f5d37a6a1:0">Props and composition give you all the flexibility you need to customize a component's look and behavior in an explicit and safe way. Remember that components may accept arbitrary props, including primitive values, React elements, or functions.</span></span>

<span key="c5371bf622f5480fb6824731a0e0a505"><span offset-key="c5371bf622f5480fb6824731a0e0a505:0">If you want to reuse non-UI functionality between components, we suggest extracting it into a separate JavaScript module. The components may import it and use that function, object, or a class, without extending it.</span></span>

# 

<span key="42986e6b28c94adca2f3562115966083">**Thinking in React**</span>

# 

<span key="2512a7e7449c4a1b801c6fdcee1201d1"><span offset-key="2512a7e7449c4a1b801c6fdcee1201d1:0">React is, in our opinion, the premier way to build big, fast Web apps with JavaScript. It has scaled very well for us at Facebook and Instagram.</span></span>

<span key="82a4b5f8dbde434aab81ffcf3608ae0f"><span offset-key="82a4b5f8dbde434aab81ffcf3608ae0f:0">One of the many great parts of React is how it makes you think about apps as you build them. In this document, we'll walk you through the thought process of building a searchable product data table using React.</span></span>

# 

<span key="f6a2665d44ff44cc96f06b1385d23b6c"><span offset-key="f6a2665d44ff44cc96f06b1385d23b6c:0">Start With A Mock</span></span>
