# 

<span key="cc61bc1e653f4e90b524dedaa52583c7"><span offset-key="cc61bc1e653f4e90b524dedaa52583c7:0">Step 1: Break The UI Into A Component Hierarchy</span></span>

<span key="53e691e619734b8d9dbc764ca2e38838"><span offset-key="53e691e619734b8d9dbc764ca2e38838:0">The first thing you'll want to do is to draw boxes around every component (and subcomponent) in the mock and give them all names. If you're working with a designer, they may have already done this, so go talk to them! Their Photoshop layer names may end up being the names of your React components!</span></span>

<span key="feb6acd28512459480ec5f6a29b74a52"><span offset-key="feb6acd28512459480ec5f6a29b74a52:0">But how do you know what should be its own component? Use the same techniques for deciding if you should create a new function or object. One such technique is the </span></span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_responsibility_principle" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="27e2ef7ccbb24289b1988b24cc11df22" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="9ff6900d7005474b9a143d1d97a078d0"><span data-offset-key="9ff6900d7005474b9a143d1d97a078d0:0">single responsibility principle</span></span></span></a><span key="15a25772257a411cab3dd30bc2e0db04"><span offset-key="15a25772257a411cab3dd30bc2e0db04:0">, that is, a component should ideally only do one thing. If it ends up growing, it should be decomposed into smaller subcomponents.</span></span>

<span key="1b3c4e8dad1f4ce5bff61802fb5a4d46"><span offset-key="1b3c4e8dad1f4ce5bff61802fb5a4d46:0">Since you're often displaying a JSON data model to a user, you'll find that if your model was built correctly, your UI (and therefore your component structure) will map nicely. That's because UI and data models tend to adhere to the same </span>*information architecture*<span offset-key="1b3c4e8dad1f4ce5bff61802fb5a4d46:2">. Separate your UI into components, where each component matches one piece of your data model.</span></span>

<span key="926ad243ab0b47df869dbe91b63bd6fd"><span offset-key="926ad243ab0b47df869dbe91b63bd6fd:0">https://reactjs.org/static/eb8bda25806a89ebdc838813bdfa3601/6b2ea/thinking-in-react-components.png</span></span>

<span key="e5c636a0690648ad9161c6224794d3ce"><span offset-key="e5c636a0690648ad9161c6224794d3ce:0">You'll see here that we have five components in our app. We've italicized the data each component represents.</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="87f40cbbc32f45a4887f6ef4381013f5">**`FilterableProductTable`** **(orange):**<span offset-key="87f40cbbc32f45a4887f6ef4381013f5:2"> contains the entirety of the example</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="ff3c7c8be603406bb6d8b3a4c3e8e620">**`SearchBar`** **(blue):**<span offset-key="ff3c7c8be603406bb6d8b3a4c3e8e620:2"> receives all </span>*user input*</span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="51f45af7741946c19bcd180d9fa5d450">**`ProductTable`** **(green):**<span offset-key="51f45af7741946c19bcd180d9fa5d450:2"> displays and filters the </span>*data collection*<span offset-key="51f45af7741946c19bcd180d9fa5d450:4"> based on </span>*user input*</span>

4.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">4.</span>
    <span key="7f16db4919f74d269b6d25bbb0bc3561">**`ProductCategoryRow`** **(turquoise):**<span offset-key="7f16db4919f74d269b6d25bbb0bc3561:2"> displays a heading for each </span>*category*</span>

5.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">5.</span>
    <span key="1094227e5b714f9bbf74218a59aa91aa">**`ProductRow`** **(red):**<span offset-key="1094227e5b714f9bbf74218a59aa91aa:2"> displays a row for each </span>*product*</span>

<span key="26454722ecd941da963d9007b9306013"><span offset-key="26454722ecd941da963d9007b9306013:0">If you look at </span>`ProductTable`<span offset-key="26454722ecd941da963d9007b9306013:2">, you'll see that the table header (containing the "Name" and "Price" labels) isn't its own component. This is a matter of preference, and there's an argument to be made either way. For this example, we left it as part of </span>`ProductTable`<span offset-key="26454722ecd941da963d9007b9306013:4"> because it is part of rendering the </span>*data collection*<span offset-key="26454722ecd941da963d9007b9306013:6"> which is </span>`ProductTable`<span offset-key="26454722ecd941da963d9007b9306013:8">'s responsibility. However, if this header grows to be complex (e.g., if we were to add affordances for sorting), it would certainly make sense to make this its own </span>`ProductTableHeader`<span offset-key="26454722ecd941da963d9007b9306013:10"> component.</span></span>

<span key="ccc4b0f875644f9cbdb166cda9f8081e"><span offset-key="ccc4b0f875644f9cbdb166cda9f8081e:0">Now that we've identified the components in our mock, let's arrange them into a hierarchy. Components that appear within another component in the mock should appear as a child in the hierarchy:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="aa9be59e750040bc9633f26e5fe61827">`FilterableProductTable`</span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

        <span key="5f513abd738e4b22aaaab5b4c0ad25bd">`SearchBar`</span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

        <span key="a16d0da064fa498090ed8441e9ba1dda">`ProductTable`</span>

        -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

            <span key="ebe0882d939143af9c7d49b1b70c02c3">`ProductCategoryRow`</span>

        -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

            <span key="cd4f67d5ca74439e99acb3940b8dcc75">`ProductRow`</span>

# 

<span key="d13e5a1e39f346739796235050cc1df8"><span offset-key="d13e5a1e39f346739796235050cc1df8:0">Step 2: Build A Static Version in React</span></span>

<span key="8df8b6f20f58432dae5ee6cfa9955700"><span offset-key="8df8b6f20f58432dae5ee6cfa9955700:0">See the Pen </span></span><a href="https://codepen.io/gaearon/pen/BwWzwm" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="9a0476cd1c134861ac5b959e9a252438" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="8334c92ea420409f8a42889a3c9763be"><span data-offset-key="8334c92ea420409f8a42889a3c9763be:0">Thinking In React: Step 2</span></span></span></a><span key="d55d9ce62b044eec924e59857145c37e"><span offset-key="d55d9ce62b044eec924e59857145c37e:0"> on </span></span><a href="https://codepen.io" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="24cb52492f2245fb88f574492ad4fcb6" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="c744d04f3b9d4ea5901bf2acd9504181"><span data-offset-key="c744d04f3b9d4ea5901bf2acd9504181:0">CodePen</span></span></span></a><span key="42e4af1cab704952a405fc3a5fdf5292"><span offset-key="42e4af1cab704952a405fc3a5fdf5292:0">.</span></span>

<span key="151399c890df428cadc85c8079e7d293"><span offset-key="151399c890df428cadc85c8079e7d293:0">Now that you have your component hierarchy, it's time to implement your app. The easiest way is to build a version that takes your data model and renders the UI but has no interactivity. It's best to decouple these processes because building a static version requires a lot of typing and no thinking, and adding interactivity requires a lot of thinking and not a lot of typing. We'll see why.</span></span>

<span key="321309596715499c8193503ffdac5bf6"><span offset-key="321309596715499c8193503ffdac5bf6:0">To build a static version of your app that renders your data model, you'll want to build components that reuse other components and pass data using </span>*props*<span offset-key="321309596715499c8193503ffdac5bf6:2">. </span>*props*<span offset-key="321309596715499c8193503ffdac5bf6:4"> are a way of passing data from parent to child. If you're familiar with the concept of </span>*state*<span offset-key="321309596715499c8193503ffdac5bf6:6">, </span>**don't use state at all**<span offset-key="321309596715499c8193503ffdac5bf6:8"> to build this static version. State is reserved only for interactivity, that is, data that changes over time. Since this is a static version of the app, you don't need it.</span></span>

<span key="642887d4a19e483c89d06d9a7dd22ad6"><span offset-key="642887d4a19e483c89d06d9a7dd22ad6:0">You can build top-down or bottom-up. That is, you can either start with building the components higher up in the hierarchy (i.e. starting with </span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="642887d4a19e483c89d06d9a7dd22ad6:2">) or with the ones lower in it (</span>`ProductRow`<span offset-key="642887d4a19e483c89d06d9a7dd22ad6:4">). In simpler examples, it's usually easier to go top-down, and on larger projects, it's easier to go bottom-up and write tests as you build.</span></span>

<span key="68129e8da4cc40b2af563d34f26788c4"><span offset-key="68129e8da4cc40b2af563d34f26788c4:0">At the end of this step, you'll have a library of reusable components that render your data model. The components will only have </span>`render()`<span offset-key="68129e8da4cc40b2af563d34f26788c4:2"> methods since this is a static version of your app. The component at the top of the hierarchy (</span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="68129e8da4cc40b2af563d34f26788c4:4">) will take your data model as a prop. If you make a change to your underlying data model and call </span>`ReactDOM.render()`<span offset-key="68129e8da4cc40b2af563d34f26788c4:6"> again, the UI will be updated. You can see how your UI is updated and where to make changes. React's </span>**one-way data flow**<span offset-key="68129e8da4cc40b2af563d34f26788c4:8"> (also called </span>*one-way binding*<span offset-key="68129e8da4cc40b2af563d34f26788c4:10">) keeps everything modular and fast.</span></span>

<span key="8c201c156ea74d1aa8f5cb5481d8520e"><span offset-key="8c201c156ea74d1aa8f5cb5481d8520e:0">Refer to the </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c64e8edbf9134c97b1361feabeab6c65" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="b5846bbb5200410fa39ec3e7ab3aaf8d"><span data-offset-key="b5846bbb5200410fa39ec3e7ab3aaf8d:0">React docs</span></span></span></a><span key="07f539cfde6e4f60ba02eb77103b0728"><span offset-key="07f539cfde6e4f60ba02eb77103b0728:0"> if you need help executing this step.</span></span>

# 

<span key="9dc028bc635943938813c3738c8170b9"><span offset-key="9dc028bc635943938813c3738c8170b9:0">A Brief Interlude: Props vs State</span></span>

<span key="5f5ed2693de24cb79f8cf0783ad5a75e"><span offset-key="5f5ed2693de24cb79f8cf0783ad5a75e:0">There are two types of "model" data in React: props and state. It's important to understand the distinction between the two; skim </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/state-and-lifecycle.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="bba28be102564c699389ed034208bbe3" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="074ed8bb466d4eb6a3c39fc331a4319d"><span data-offset-key="074ed8bb466d4eb6a3c39fc331a4319d:0">the official React docs</span></span></span></a><span key="f566aa7b88d442c1b9572ef9d067dc25"><span offset-key="f566aa7b88d442c1b9572ef9d067dc25:0"> if you aren't sure what the difference is. See also </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/faq-state.html#what-is-the-difference-between-state-and-props" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="751965ea59c74be0b2eb05c0fa13a09b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="d1c631db46c0486788cd2dec32beda99"><span data-offset-key="d1c631db46c0486788cd2dec32beda99:0">FAQ: What is the difference between state and props?</span></span></span></a><span key="743f5b5a7ac846e4aa8fc5fdd7be429c"><span offset-key="743f5b5a7ac846e4aa8fc5fdd7be429c:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

# 

<span key="90b5614367ac4e3391a5a4aeedc1cce4"><span offset-key="90b5614367ac4e3391a5a4aeedc1cce4:0">Step 3: Identify The Minimal (but complete) Representation Of UI State</span></span>

<span key="54b3d10b4a5a4bfab850eb2f43191c44"><span offset-key="54b3d10b4a5a4bfab850eb2f43191c44:0">To make your UI interactive, you need to be able to trigger changes to your underlying data model. React achieves this with </span>**state**<span offset-key="54b3d10b4a5a4bfab850eb2f43191c44:2">.</span></span>

<span key="f239ff8a26c24043b44986a7a80367ce"><span offset-key="f239ff8a26c24043b44986a7a80367ce:0">To build your app correctly, you first need to think of the minimal set of mutable state that your app needs. The key here is </span></span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don&#39;t_repeat_yourself" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a501ac924a43471da5cf2b01586050b2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="04d8ecfa13a145698c5e08fb971df04e"><span data-offset-key="04d8ecfa13a145698c5e08fb971df04e:0">DRY: </span><em>Don't Repeat Yourself</em></span></span></a><span key="e4c95bb47bb94131ac8421df269f22d7"><span offset-key="e4c95bb47bb94131ac8421df269f22d7:0">. Figure out the absolute minimal representation of the state your application needs and compute everything else you need on-demand. For example, if you're building a TODO list, keep an array of the TODO items around; don't keep a separate state variable for the count. Instead, when you want to render the TODO count, take the length of the TODO items array.</span></span>

<span key="27ba493bebfc4327ab96e6d8ffbdf9c7"><span offset-key="27ba493bebfc4327ab96e6d8ffbdf9c7:0">Think of all the pieces of data in our example application. We have:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="1e2b4231c4894cc4bb2c5caf8a718373"><span offset-key="1e2b4231c4894cc4bb2c5caf8a718373:0">The original list of products</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="888710a71e8b4d5481597880225daafd"><span offset-key="888710a71e8b4d5481597880225daafd:0">The search text the user has entered</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="5c438d90163a4e32a8d0992f4b0c09b1"><span offset-key="5c438d90163a4e32a8d0992f4b0c09b1:0">The value of the checkbox</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="61361e40caab47809e73f70c35564834"><span offset-key="61361e40caab47809e73f70c35564834:0">The filtered list of products</span></span>

<span key="dd620b5d7c524cbcad3dc235b7b32245"><span offset-key="dd620b5d7c524cbcad3dc235b7b32245:0">Let's go through each one and figure out which one is state. Ask three questions about each piece of data:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="9737a0d05d4d4c8094ac791408b58409"><span offset-key="9737a0d05d4d4c8094ac791408b58409:0">Is it passed in from a parent via props? If so, it probably isn't state.</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="6f35cffba8404d8b83d92dcaeb4a3907"><span offset-key="6f35cffba8404d8b83d92dcaeb4a3907:0">Does it remain unchanged over time? If so, it probably isn't state.</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="5425fbabc4a741e784f6f02e044b49e5"><span offset-key="5425fbabc4a741e784f6f02e044b49e5:0">Can you compute it based on any other state or props in your component? If so, it isn't state.</span></span>

<span key="e28c26c32bbb4445b16721df53df9200"><span offset-key="e28c26c32bbb4445b16721df53df9200:0">The original list of products is passed in as props, so that's not state. The search text and the checkbox seem to be state since they change over time and can't be computed from anything. And finally, the filtered list of products isn't state because it can be computed by combining the original list of products with the search text and value of the checkbox.</span></span>

<span key="78279b07d1634bd59c367dac2db4b333"><span offset-key="78279b07d1634bd59c367dac2db4b333:0">So finally, our state is:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="5a9edb49b12a4520a836f16faeeefe96"><span offset-key="5a9edb49b12a4520a836f16faeeefe96:0">The search text the user has entered</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="f699bbd51eb545e4beec4b2ab7021deb"><span offset-key="f699bbd51eb545e4beec4b2ab7021deb:0">The value of the checkbox</span></span>

# 

<span key="832a145828ea4373aec539ecea039408"><span offset-key="832a145828ea4373aec539ecea039408:0">Step 4: Identify Where Your State Should Live</span></span>

<span key="6024c94cd048455683265abef16fd298"><span offset-key="6024c94cd048455683265abef16fd298:0">See the Pen </span></span><a href="https://codepen.io/gaearon/pen/qPrNQZ" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="26f4c2654c7f4d229540330184e4cda8" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="a050b2311f8247ad983ca125c78ff879"><span data-offset-key="a050b2311f8247ad983ca125c78ff879:0">Thinking In React: Step 4</span></span></span></a><span key="d3b88b1018e8488587bb5567a75dc6b3"><span offset-key="d3b88b1018e8488587bb5567a75dc6b3:0"> on </span></span><a href="https://codepen.io" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="dba4d52522e74610a2696209b91b76e2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="dc2fb33ef23e4f8db3086f050a31d797"><span data-offset-key="dc2fb33ef23e4f8db3086f050a31d797:0">CodePen</span></span></span></a><span key="2ce2e40c5f314497a8f741a20f87048e"><span offset-key="2ce2e40c5f314497a8f741a20f87048e:0">.</span></span>

<span key="1012fc0e6c7d4947a9b9c9488095bc09"><span offset-key="1012fc0e6c7d4947a9b9c9488095bc09:0">OK, so we've identified what the minimal set of app state is. Next, we need to identify which component mutates, or </span>*owns*<span offset-key="1012fc0e6c7d4947a9b9c9488095bc09:2">, this state.</span></span>

<span key="09f3694929eb4d1995bb0e43fc1694c8"><span offset-key="09f3694929eb4d1995bb0e43fc1694c8:0">Remember: React is all about one-way data flow down the component hierarchy. It may not be immediately clear which component should own what state. </span>**This is often the most challenging part for newcomers to understand,**<span offset-key="09f3694929eb4d1995bb0e43fc1694c8:2"> so follow these steps to figure it out:</span></span>

<span key="7e51d42e89ff4d3cabb759d4d98327e2"><span offset-key="7e51d42e89ff4d3cabb759d4d98327e2:0">For each piece of state in your application:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="7a0be318c01b4dee87da2439dbd39559"><span offset-key="7a0be318c01b4dee87da2439dbd39559:0">Identify every component that renders something based on that state.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="f1103bea7ecb4c79ac25f2f79ed33508"><span offset-key="f1103bea7ecb4c79ac25f2f79ed33508:0">Find a common owner component (a single component above all the components that need the state in the hierarchy).</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="0c0b6eccd6254c408fc547a29121db42"><span offset-key="0c0b6eccd6254c408fc547a29121db42:0">Either the common owner or another component higher up in the hierarchy should own the state.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="10abc8b1cee446189c03d698f359383c"><span offset-key="10abc8b1cee446189c03d698f359383c:0">If you can't find a component where it makes sense to own the state, create a new component solely for holding the state and add it somewhere in the hierarchy above the common owner component.</span></span>

<span key="d04e53c7dc624d3db1df8841e29eb62f"><span offset-key="d04e53c7dc624d3db1df8841e29eb62f:0">Let's run through this strategy for our application:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="96409a37409045329edfabbf73b867cf">`ProductTable`<span offset-key="96409a37409045329edfabbf73b867cf:1"> needs to filter the product list based on state and </span>`SearchBar`<span offset-key="96409a37409045329edfabbf73b867cf:3"> needs to display the search text and checked state.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="8508fb0b4f154742a577dfa0d62a4cce"><span offset-key="8508fb0b4f154742a577dfa0d62a4cce:0">The common owner component is </span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="8508fb0b4f154742a577dfa0d62a4cce:2">.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="df7b8aa4d2d54c239667591981d27148"><span offset-key="df7b8aa4d2d54c239667591981d27148:0">It conceptually makes sense for the filter text and checked value to live in </span>`FilterableProductTable`</span>

<span key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd"><span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:0">Cool, so we've decided that our state lives in </span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:2">. First, add an instance property </span>`this.state = {filterText: '', inStockOnly: false}`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:4"> to </span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:6">'s </span>`constructor`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:8"> to reflect the initial state of your application. Then, pass </span>`filterText`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:10"> and </span>`inStockOnly`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:12"> to </span>`ProductTable`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:14"> and </span>`SearchBar`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:16"> as a prop. Finally, use these props to filter the rows in </span>`ProductTable`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:18"> and set the values of the form fields in </span>`SearchBar`<span offset-key="6afb4afd31024e55809097591fa8f3fd:20">.</span></span>

<span key="fdc6779e4ad140d9812cea4f71df6d76"><span offset-key="fdc6779e4ad140d9812cea4f71df6d76:0">You can start seeing how your application will behave: set </span>`filterText`<span offset-key="fdc6779e4ad140d9812cea4f71df6d76:2"> to </span>`"ball"`<span offset-key="fdc6779e4ad140d9812cea4f71df6d76:4"> and refresh your app. You'll see that the data table is updated correctly.</span></span>

# 

<span key="be3964a7982d42bcb7d6907a60a23100"><span offset-key="be3964a7982d42bcb7d6907a60a23100:0">Step 5: Add Inverse Data Flow</span></span>

<span key="811585197c30493eb271a29932ade433"><span offset-key="811585197c30493eb271a29932ade433:0">See the Pen </span></span><a href="https://codepen.io/gaearon/pen/LzWZvb" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f212fa32e9724bd18d178876a1c6ab1f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="d04a078b8c694620b87ece592706b712"><span data-offset-key="d04a078b8c694620b87ece592706b712:0">Thinking In React: Step 5</span></span></span></a><span key="955e52fba3e049c6b30429553f6ef930"><span offset-key="955e52fba3e049c6b30429553f6ef930:0"> on </span></span><a href="https://codepen.io" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="44b2067827ad44719565924069c07567" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="764f8908562943af879372c3818fc204"><span data-offset-key="764f8908562943af879372c3818fc204:0">CodePen</span></span></span></a><span key="5610a53edbb1441dae1d1516cee77317"><span offset-key="5610a53edbb1441dae1d1516cee77317:0">.</span></span>

<span key="f35feb6b02f244b6b5a206465db877b1"><span offset-key="f35feb6b02f244b6b5a206465db877b1:0">So far, we've built an app that renders correctly as a function of props and state flowing down the hierarchy. Now it's time to support data flowing the other way: the form components deep in the hierarchy need to update the state in </span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="f35feb6b02f244b6b5a206465db877b1:2">.</span></span>

<span key="177306adc4f44622b2e1c2570e01baa0"><span offset-key="177306adc4f44622b2e1c2570e01baa0:0">React makes this data flow explicit to help you understand how your program works, but it does require a little more typing than traditional two-way data binding.</span></span>

<span key="1bafbb79d7434398a317d267b4824f13"><span offset-key="1bafbb79d7434398a317d267b4824f13:0">If you try to type or check the box in the current version of the example, you'll see that React ignores your input. This is intentional, as we've set the </span>`value`<span offset-key="1bafbb79d7434398a317d267b4824f13:2"> prop of the </span>`input`<span offset-key="1bafbb79d7434398a317d267b4824f13:4"> to always be equal to the </span>`state`<span offset-key="1bafbb79d7434398a317d267b4824f13:6"> passed in from </span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="1bafbb79d7434398a317d267b4824f13:8">.</span></span>

<span key="470a3d1e150f4ccf9a229ef32962eb09"><span offset-key="470a3d1e150f4ccf9a229ef32962eb09:0">Let's think about what we want to happen. We want to make sure that whenever the user changes the form, we update the state to reflect the user input. Since components should only update their own state, </span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="470a3d1e150f4ccf9a229ef32962eb09:2"> will pass callbacks to </span>`SearchBar`<span offset-key="470a3d1e150f4ccf9a229ef32962eb09:4"> that will fire whenever the state should be updated. We can use the </span>`onChange`<span offset-key="470a3d1e150f4ccf9a229ef32962eb09:6"> event on the inputs to be notified of it. The callbacks passed by </span>`FilterableProductTable`<span offset-key="470a3d1e150f4ccf9a229ef32962eb09:8"> will call </span>`setState()`<span offset-key="470a3d1e150f4ccf9a229ef32962eb09:10">, and the app will be updated.</span></span>

# 

<span key="dbf2a3bd68b34ef080f7065dc6e47c7c"><span offset-key="dbf2a3bd68b34ef080f7065dc6e47c7c:0">And That's It</span></span>

<span key="84f99a65a97347829c4f49a5495674c4"><span offset-key="84f99a65a97347829c4f49a5495674c4:0">Hopefully, this gives you an idea of how to think about building components and applications with React. While it may be a little more typing than you're used to, remember that code is read far more than it's written, and it's less difficult to read this modular, explicit code. As you start to build large libraries of components, you'll appreciate this explicitness and modularity, and with code reuse, your lines of code will start to shrink. :)</span></span>

<span key="d17bfd4fd8bc403b87f754c0800f5a04"><span offset-key="d17bfd4fd8bc403b87f754c0800f5a04:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://www.notion.so/React-Component-3dc17bc49a8e4d7e89efcc1281e747d9" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2f07e46e28194a6586a99bf7b2911b44" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="22653dfad1eb4e919cc14fa25380a282"><span data-offset-key="22653dfad1eb4e919cc14fa25380a282:0">React Component</span></span></span></a><span key="bf664df6174145abbfa9729b4d332db1"><span offset-key="bf664df6174145abbfa9729b4d332db1:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="ecfc8cd5fcad4ca7bae7459d83c732a9"><span offset-key="ecfc8cd5fcad4ca7bae7459d83c732a9:0">This appendix is a non-exhaustive list of new syntactic features and methods that were added to JavaScript in ES6. These features are the most commonly used and most helpful.</span></span>

<span key="e83455061478454096fbaec588acfcfc"><span offset-key="e83455061478454096fbaec588acfcfc:0">While this appendix doesn't cover ES6 classes, we go over the basics while learning about components in the book. In addition, this appendix doesn't include descriptions of some larger new features like promises and generators. If you'd like more info on those or on any topic below, we encourage you to reference the </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="db24c438e2344bed87be18f108038425" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-22556_259-22557-237__"><span data-key="58c62c43abe84985abe9edf0cf5a93c4"><span data-offset-key="58c62c43abe84985abe9edf0cf5a93c4:0">Mozilla Developer Network's website</span></span></span></a><span key="cff498ed79da408e8b7d079a6a0e9836"><span offset-key="cff498ed79da408e8b7d079a6a0e9836:0"> (MDN).</span></span>

### 

<span key="ce16c3f692944a7582ac613012257790"><span offset-key="ce16c3f692944a7582ac613012257790:0">Prefer </span>`const`<span offset-key="ce16c3f692944a7582ac613012257790:2"> and </span>`let`<span offset-key="ce16c3f692944a7582ac613012257790:4"> over </span>`var`</span>

<span key="ed2f7340e21346d0a3902fb56c8a910a"><span offset-key="ed2f7340e21346d0a3902fb56c8a910a:0">If you've worked with ES5 JavaScript before, you're likely used to seeing variables declared with </span>`var`<span offset-key="ed2f7340e21346d0a3902fb56c8a910a:2">:</span></span>

1

<span key="9942bd92848b43deb27015d875b51d01"><span class="r-y7gyvo" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="9942bd92848b43deb27015d875b51d01:0">var</span><span offset-key="9942bd92848b43deb27015d875b51d01:1"> myVariable </span><span class="r-11faab8" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="9942bd92848b43deb27015d875b51d01:2">=</span><span offset-key="9942bd92848b43deb27015d875b51d01:3"> </span><span class="r-11faab8" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="9942bd92848b43deb27015d875b51d01:4">5</span><span class="r-dyg9za" slate-leaf="true" offset-key="9942bd92848b43deb27015d875b51d01:5">;</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="10ae1b974c4d458fadc4a05776c20ece"><span offset-key="10ae1b974c4d458fadc4a05776c20ece:0">Both the </span>`const`<span offset-key="10ae1b974c4d458fadc4a05776c20ece:2"> and </span>`let`<span offset-key="10ae1b974c4d458fadc4a05776c20ece:4"> statements also declare variables. They were introduced in ES6.</span></span>

<span key="7d16a605af004cb9ab533475ac0a391c"><span offset-key="7d16a605af004cb9ab533475ac0a391c:0">Use </span>`const`<span offset-key="7d16a605af004cb9ab533475ac0a391c:2"> in cases where a variable is never re-assigned. Using </span>`const`<span offset-key="7d16a605af004cb9ab533475ac0a391c:4"> makes this clear to whoever is reading your code. It refers to the "constant" state of the variable in the context it is defined within.</span></span>

<span key="19866f391656469482354fcf12a61321"><span offset-key="19866f391656469482354fcf12a61321:0">If the variable will be re-assigned, use </span>`let`<span offset-key="19866f391656469482354fcf12a61321:2">.</span></span>

<span key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e"><span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:0">We encourage the use of </span>`const`<span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:2"> and </span>`let`<span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:4"> instead of </span>`var`<span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:6">. In addition to the restriction introduced by </span>`const`<span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:8">, both </span>`const`<span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:10"> and </span>`let`<span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:12"> are </span>*block scoped*<span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:14"> as opposed to </span>*function scoped*<span offset-key="5107082ad5f94230b1de9cb4a3eb3b6e:16">. This scoping can help avoid unexpected bugs.</span></span>

<span key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef"><span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:0">The method </span>`printSongs()`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:2"> iterates over </span>`this.songs`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:4"> with </span>`forEach()`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:6">. In this context, </span>`this`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:8"> is bound to the object (</span>`jukebox`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:10">) as expected. However, the anonymous function passed to </span>`forEach()`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:12"> binds its internal </span>`this`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:14"> to the global object. As such, </span>`this.printSong(song)`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:16"> calls the function declared at the top of the example, </span>*not*<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:18"> the method on </span>`jukebox`<span offset-key="c0958f5ef80c4a7c9b174b11356d55ef:20">.</span></span>

<span key="658fca8b2bde46e48cc3d0474b945556"><span offset-key="658fca8b2bde46e48cc3d0474b945556:0">JavaScript developers have traditionally used workarounds for this behavior, but arrow functions solve the problem by </span>**capturing the** **`this`** **value of the enclosing context**<span offset-key="658fca8b2bde46e48cc3d0474b945556:4">. Using an arrow function for </span>`printSongs()`<span offset-key="658fca8b2bde46e48cc3d0474b945556:6"> has the expected result:</span></span>

<span key="de90eeaccaaf413da4ae78e5c9b88271"><span offset-key="de90eeaccaaf413da4ae78e5c9b88271:0">Modules</span></span>

<span key="88706f6bde3b403fb2fab590c8a3891e"><span offset-key="88706f6bde3b403fb2fab590c8a3891e:0">ES6 formally supports modules using the </span>`import`<span offset-key="88706f6bde3b403fb2fab590c8a3891e:2">/</span>`export`<span offset-key="88706f6bde3b403fb2fab590c8a3891e:4"> syntax.</span></span>

<span key="76b9322740d54cc883b940488792f4e3">**Named exports**</span>

Here's an example of a file that exports two functions:</span></span>

1

<span key="10eed9f777824d2eab77dfb03e819dbd"><span offset-key="10eed9f777824d2eab77dfb03e819dbd:0">Importantly, the function that was </span>*not*<span offset-key="10eed9f777824d2eab77dfb03e819dbd:2"> exported (</span>`saySomething`<span offset-key="10eed9f777824d2eab77dfb03e819dbd:4">) is unavailable outside of the module.</span></span>

<span key="a15976cde6294d09bc1bab98a9df0a9a"><span offset-key="a15976cde6294d09bc1bab98a9df0a9a:0">Also note that we supply a </span>**relative path**<span offset-key="a15976cde6294d09bc1bab98a9df0a9a:2"> to </span>`from`<span offset-key="a15976cde6294d09bc1bab98a9df0a9a:4">, indicating that the ES6 module is a local file as opposed to an npm package.</span></span>

<span key="eca9bfe04bb640f09853060a257eec34"><span offset-key="eca9bfe04bb640f09853060a257eec34:0">Instead of inserting an </span>`export`<span offset-key="eca9bfe04bb640f09853060a257eec34:2"> before each variable you'd like to export, you can use this syntax to list off all the exposed variables in one area:</span></span>

1

### 

<span key="f21a10d8f7ff4adaa30f1d0bc41dfb25">`Object.assign()`</span>

<span key="8fef7820ca2f4ceeb0a1ff08a5b9aeb0"><span offset-key="8fef7820ca2f4ceeb0a1ff08a5b9aeb0:0">We use </span>`Object.assign()`<span offset-key="8fef7820ca2f4ceeb0a1ff08a5b9aeb0:2"> often throughout the book. We use it in areas where we want to create a modified version of an existing object.</span></span>

<span key="8fdd8255e9704334ad57f92235e1dfec">`Object.assign()`<span offset-key="8fdd8255e9704334ad57f92235e1dfec:1"> accepts any number of objects as arguments. When the function receives two arguments, it </span>*copies*<span offset-key="8fdd8255e9704334ad57f92235e1dfec:3"> the properties of the second object onto the first, like so:</span></span>

1

<span key="a17b9455959d4d31b46417d287d0a3b3">**For arrays**</span>

2
